Award.AwardTitle: AGS-PRF: The Tropical Marine Boundary Layer Moisture Field Using S-Pol Data from DYNAMO and Comparison with RICO
Award.AbstractNarration:
Due to the highly variable nature of the moisture field in the tropical marine boundary layer (TMBL), it has largely been characterized in terms of its mean state. Yet, when and where convection is initiated, how long clouds persist, and precipitation amount and distribution is controlled by the actual distribution of moisture. Existing data sets capable of characterizing the large-scale moisture field over the equatorial Indian Ocean (based largely on a combination of satellite and sounding measurements) are insufficient for understanding Madden-Julian Oscillation (MJO) initiation. The need for better resolved, more frequent, higher quality moisture measurements was one of the primary motivating factors for the joint Dynamics of the MJO (DYNAMO) Experiment in the Year 2011 - such data was deemed critical for testing many of the leading MJO initiation hypotheses. Despite the extensive set of measurements made to document the moisture field (including ~20,000 soundings), the extreme moisture variability in the TMBL documented during the Rain in Cumulus over the Ocean (RICO) Experiment indicates that these combined measurements may still be insufficient.

Previously developed radar product was used to map the mean mesoscale moisture field structure during RICO, based on Bragg scattering layers (BSLs) detectable with S-band dual-polarization radar (S-Pol). BSL analysis provides an unprecedented structural context for both marrying together and more accurately interpreting moisture retrievals generated at a variety of scales and resolutions. This proposal is centered on conducting BSL analysis on S-Pol data from DYNAMO. BSL results will be combined with other DYNAMO humidity retrievals (e.g. from satellite, soundings, scanning microwave radiometer) to produce the most complete mapping of the TMBL moisture field to date. TMBL moisture field statistics will be generated and the controls on its structure will be investigated (e.g., time of day, wind direction and speed, rain rate, MJO phase). Island induced biases will be examined through a new BSL-based analysis technique. DYNAMO statistical results will be compared to RICO's to look for key similarities and differences in TMBL structure. A BSL-based, large eddy simulation validation technique will also be explored.

Intellectual Merit:
The research addresses fundamental science questions about moisture variability and the mean structure typifying the TMBL over the equatorial, central Indian Ocean. Comparison of DYNAMO and RICO results will likely reveal both key commonalities - that can then be assumed true for TMBLs in general, and statistical differences - perhaps from differences in large-scale dynamics.

Broader Impacts:
The mapping of the TMBL moisture field structure will be extremely valuable for testing MJO initiation hypotheses. MJO contributes significantly to tropical intraseasonal variability and interacts with many systems to greatly enhance extreme weather events in the tropics and at higher latitudes. BSL analysis can also improve our ability to produce short-term forecasts.

of detection. While yielding quality measurements, each sounding provides only a single strand of near-instantaneous data which we often assume is representative of the atmosphere over a much larger area for a much longer
time. The problem is we rarely know whether or not this assumption of
representativeness is good. Bragg scattering layer (BSL) analysis is a new
technique that allows us to utilize already existing S-band radar data sets to
make judgement calls about sounding representativeness (Fig.1).

The primary data sets for this research are the National Center for Atmospheric Research's (NCAR's) S-Pol radar data and the Atmospheric Radiation Measurement (ARM) soundings from the joint DYNAMO (Dynamics of the Madden Julian Oscillation (MJO)) and AMIE (ARM MJO Investigation Experiment) projects. By examining how the Bragg layers varied over the radar domain, I was able to identify 19 days where a sea breeze / heat island circulation was able to develop at the Gan site, biasing many of the sounding mixed layer top altitude estimates high by hundreds of meters (Fig. 2). Because this circulation is linked to the diurnal cycle and it was intended for the Gan site measurements to be representative of the larger marine environment, it is important to identify these cases since inclusion of these soundings in project statistics can potentially mask other trends. These results are currently being written up for publication.

Data rarely comes ready to use and BSL analysis has different quality requirements than traditional radar data usage. This data set required development of techniques to 1) address over-filtering of data at lower-altitude range gates with (near) zero radial velocity and 2) remove spurious signals from side lobe artifacts. While S-band radar data is normally sampled by sweeping the radar beam in a series of nested cones (PPIs), vertical slices (RHIs) were a regular part of the DYNAMO radar data set, and the BSL analysis technique was adapted to make use of this RHI data, too. The latter two portions of this work resulted in a refereed publication, while the technique for dealing with over-filtering will be included in the island bias write-up. 

 

Understanding the background state of the environment is necessary to understanding and being able to predict weather phenomena. Usually, environmental characterization is provided by taking multiple soundings and interpolating between them (in both space and time) using models or other analysis techniques. For environments with fairly uniform conditions that change slowly with time this is an acceptable methodology, but if conditions are highly variable and/or change rapidly, such characterizations can be misleading. BSL analysis is being used to provide a context for interpreting sounding profiles, to better understand how changes in the background environment come about. Although BSL analysis does not provide quantitative information about the moisture content of the environment, it does provide high temporal resolution, radar-mean altitude estimates for many significant boundaries such as the tops of the mixed layer, transition layer, and moist layer. Bragg scattering layer (BSL) analysis is a new technique that allows us to utilize already existing S-band radar data sets to make judgement calls about sounding representativeness (Fig.1). These results are currently being written up for publication. Data rarely comes ready to use and BSL analysis has different quality requirements than traditional radar data usage. This data set required development of techniques to 1) address over-filtering of data at lower-altitude range gates with (near) zero radial velocity and 2) remove spurious signals from side lobe artifacts. While S-band radar data is normally sampled by sweeping the radar beam in a series of nested cones (PPIs), vertical slices (RHIs) were a regular part of the DYNAMO radar data set, and the BSL analysis technique was adapted to make use of this RHI data, too. Usually, environmental characterization is provided by taking multiple soundings and interpolating between them (in both space and time) using models or other analysis techniques. For environments with fairly uniform conditions that change slowly with time this is an acceptable methodology, but if conditions are highly variable and/or change rapidly, such characterizations can be misleading. An example of one of the completed portions of this analysis, the diurnal cycle of the mixed layer top by MJO phase, can be seen in Fig. 3. The sample size of these measurements helps bridge the gap in scales between satellite measurements and sounding profiles, and will be used to help understand why moisture measurements from these two sources can often disagree in tropical marine environments.
